briefdescription.para: Use heigh raycasting normal for max slope calculation.

detaileddescription.para: True if maxSlope is less than 90 degrees.

briefdescription.para: Width of the grid in nodes.
Depth (height) of the grid in nodes.
Scaling of the graph along the X axis.

detaileddescription.para: This should be used if you want different scales on the X and Y axis of the grid

briefdescription.para: Rotation of the grid in degrees.
Center point of the grid.
Size of the grid.

detaileddescription.para: Might be negative or smaller than nodeSize

briefdescription.para: Size of one node in world units.
Settings on how to check for walkability and height.
The max position difference between two nodes to enable a connection.

detaileddescription.para: Set to 0 to ignore the value.

briefdescription.para: The axis to use for maxClimb.
The max slope in degrees for a node to be walkable.
Erosion of the graph.

detaileddescription.para: The graph can be eroded after calculation. This means a margin is put around unwalkable nodes or other unwalkable connections. It is really good if your graph contains ledges where the nodes without erosion are walkable too close to the edge.
Below is an image showing a graph with erode iterations 0, 1 and 2

simplesect.para: A high number of erode iterations can seriously slow down graph updates during runtime (GraphUpdateObject) and should be kept as low as possible.

briefdescription.para: Use tags instead of walkability for erosion.

detaileddescription.para:
Tags will be used for erosion instead of marking nodes as unwalkable. The nodes will be marked with tags in an increasing order starting with the tag erosionFirstTag. Debug with the Tags mode to see the effect. With this enabled you can in effect set how close different AIs are allowed to get to walls using the Valid Tags field on the Seeker component.
erosionFirstTag

briefdescription.para: Tag to start from when using tags for erosion.
Auto link the graph's edge nodes together with other GridGraphs in the scene on Scan.
Distance limit for grid graphs to be auto linked.
Number of neighbours for each node.

detaileddescription.para: Either four directional or eight directional

briefdescription.para: If disabled, will not cut corners on obstacles.

detaileddescription.para: If connections is Eight, obstacle corners might be cut by a connection, setting this to false disables that.

briefdescription.para: Offset for the position when calculating penalty.
Use position (y-coordinate) to calculate penalty.
Scale factor for penalty when calculating from position.
Holds settings for using a texture as source for a grid graph.

detaileddescription.para:
Texure data can be used for fine grained control over how the graph will look. It can be used for positioning, penalty and walkability control. Below is a screenshot of a grid graph with a penalty map applied. It has the effect of the AI taking the longer path along the green (low penalty) areas.
Color data is got as 0...255 values. A* Pro Feature: This is an A* Pathfinding Project Pro feature only. This function/class/variable might not exist in the Free version of the A* Pathfinding Project or the functionality might be limited The Pro version can be bought here Can only be used with Unity 3.4 and up

briefdescription.para: This is placed here so generators inheriting from this one can override it and set it to false.

detaileddescription.para: If it is true, it means that the nodes array's length will always be equal to width*depth It is used mainly in the editor to do auto-scanning calls, setting it to false for a non-uniform grid will reduce the number of scans

briefdescription.para: In GetNearestForce, determines how far to search after a valid node has been found.
Costs to neighbour nodes.
Index offset to get neighbour nodes.

detaileddescription.para: Added to a node's index to get a neighbour node index

briefdescription.para: Offsets in the X direction for neighbour nodes.

detaileddescription.para: Only 1, 0 or -1

briefdescription.para: Offsets in the Z direction for neighbour nodes.

detaileddescription.para: Only 1, 0 or -1

briefdescription.para: Size of the grid.

detaileddescription.para:
Will always be positive and larger than nodeSize.
GenerateMatrix

briefdescription.para: To reduce memory allocations this array is reused.

detaileddescription.para:
Used in the CalculateConnections function
CalculateConnections

memberdef.argsstring: (GraphNode n1, GraphNode n2, List< Vector3 > left, List< Vector3 > right)
memberdef.name: AddPortal

briefdescription.para: Add the portal between node n1 and n2 to the funnel corridor.

detaileddescription.para: The left and right edges does not necesarily need to be the left and right edges (right can be left), they will be swapped if that is detected. But that works only as long as the edges do not switch between left and right in the middle of the path.

briefdescription.para: Calculates the grid connections for a single node.
Returns if node is connected to it's neighbour in the specified direction.

detaileddescription.para: This will also return true if neighbours = NumNeighbours.Four, the direction is diagonal and one can move through one of the adjacent nodes to the targeted node.

briefdescription.para: Creates a number of nodes with the correct type for the graph.

detaileddescription.para: This should not set the #nodes array, only return the nodes. Called by graph generators and when deserializing a graph with nodes. Override this function if you do not use the default Pathfinding.Node class.

briefdescription.para: Erodes the walkable area.

briefdescription.para: Erodes the walkable area.

detaileddescription.para: xmin, zmin (inclusive) xmax, zmax (exclusive)

briefdescription.para: Calculates minimum and maximum points for bounds b when multiplied with the matrix.

briefdescription.para: Get the connecting node from the node at (x,z) in the specified direction.

memberdef.name: HasNodeConnection

briefdescription.para: Returns true if a connection between the adjacent nodes n1 and n2 is valid.

detaileddescription.para: Also takes into account if the nodes are walkable

briefdescription.para: Returns if _b is visible from _a on the graph.

detaileddescription.para:
This is not the same as Physics.Linecast, this function traverses the graph and looks for collisions. A* Pro Feature:

briefdescription.para: Returns if _b is visible from _a on the graph.

parameterdescription.para:
If you have some idea of what the start node might be (the one close to _a), pass it to hint since it can enable faster lookups This is not the same as Physics.Linecast, this function traverses the graph and looks for collisions. A* Pro Feature:

briefdescription.para: Returns if _b is visible from _a on the graph.

parameterdescription.para: Contains info on what was hit, see GraphHitInfo

If you have some idea of what the start node might be (the one close to _a), pass it to hint since it can enable faster lookups This is not the same as Physics.Linecast, this function traverses the graph and looks for collisions. A* Pro Feature:

briefdescription.para: This function will be called when this graph is destroyed.
Auto links grid graphs together.

detaileddescription.para:
Called after all graphs have been scanned.
autoLinkGrids

briefdescription.para: Called after all deserialization has been done for all graphs.

detaileddescription.para: Can be used to set up more graph data which is not serialized

briefdescription.para: Scans the graph, called from AstarPath.Scan Override this function to implement custom scanning logic

memberdef.argsstring: (int index, int x, int z, int dir, bool value)
memberdef.name: SetNodeConnection

briefdescription.para: Set if connection in the specified direction should be enabled.

detaileddescription.para: Note that bounds checking will still be done when getting the connection value again, so it is not necessarily true that HasNodeConnection will return true just because you used SetNodeConnection on a node to set a connection to true.

briefdescription.para: Sets up neighbourOffsets with the current settings.

detaileddescription.para: neighbourOffsets, neighbourCosts, neighbourXOffsets and neighbourZOffsets are set up. The cost for a non-diagonal movement between two adjacent nodes is RoundToInt (nodeSize * Int3.Precision) The cost for a diagonal movement between two adjacent nodes is RoundToInt (nodeSize * Sqrt (2) * Int3.Precision)

memberdef.argsstring: (Vector3 _a, Vector3 _b, GraphNode hint, out GraphHitInfo hit)
memberdef.name: SnappedLinecast

briefdescription.para: Returns if _b is visible from _a on the graph.

detaileddescription.para: This function is different from the other Linecast functions since it 1) snaps the start and end positions directly to the graph and it uses Bresenham's line drawing algorithm as opposed to the others which use sampling at fixed intervals. If you only care about if one node can see another node, then this function is great, but if you need more precision than one node, use the normal linecast functions

_a
Point to linecast from
_b
Point to linecast to
hit
Contains info on what was hit, see GraphHitInfo
hint
If you have some idea of what the start node might be (the one close to _a), pass it to hint since it can enable faster lookups
This is not the same as Physics.Linecast, this function traverses the graph and looks for collisions. A* Pro Feature:
This is an A* Pathfinding Project Pro feature only. This function/class/variable might not exist in the Free version of the A* Pathfinding Project or the functionality might be limited The Pro version can be bought here

Updates position, walkability and penalty for the node.

detaileddescription.para: Assumes that collision.Initialize (...) has been called before this function

briefdescription.para: Updates size from width, depth and nodeSize values.

detaileddescription.para:
Also generates a new matrix .
This does not rescan the graph, that must be done with Scan

briefdescription.para: Calculates the grid connections for a single node.

Convenience function, it's faster to use CalculateConnections(GridNode[],int,int,node) but that will only show when calculating for a large number of nodes Todo
Test this function, should work ok, but you never know

briefdescription.para: All nodes inside the shape or if null, the bounding box.

detaileddescription.para:
If a shape is supplied, it is assumed to be contained inside the bounding box.
GraphUpdateShape.GetBounds

briefdescription.para: Generates a grid of nodes.

detaileddescription.para:
The GridGraph does exactly what the name implies, generates nodes in a grid pattern. Grid graphs suit well to when you already have a grid based world. Features:
You can update the graph during runtime (good for e.g Tower Defence or RTS games)
Throw any scene at it, with minimal configurations you can get a good graph from it.
Supports raycast and the funnel algorithm
Predictable pattern
Can apply penalty and walkability values from a supplied image
Perfect for terrain worlds since it can make areas unwalkable depending on the slope

The The Snap Size button snaps the internal size of the graph to exactly contain the current number of nodes, i.e not contain 100.3 nodes but exactly 100 nodes. This will make the "center" coordinate more accurate.

The Graph During Runtime Any graph which implements the IUpdatableGraph interface can be updated during runtime. For grid graphs this is a great feature since you can update only a small part of the grid without causing any lag like a complete rescan would. If you for example just have instantiated a sphere obstacle in the scene and you want to update the grid where that sphere was instantiated, you can do this: AstarPath.active.UpdateGraphs(ob.collider.bounds); Where ob is the obstacle you just instantiated (a GameObject). As you can see, the UpdateGraphs function takes a Bounds parameter and it will send an update call to all updateable graphs. A grid graph will update that area and a small margin around it equal to collision testing diameter/2
graph-updates for more info about updating Graph Types during runtime
